sub_title: Hoogleraar Technische Natuurkunde (Professor of Applied Physics) at Delft University of Technology
summary: In my research group we study structures built from individual magnetic atoms. Using a Scanning Tunneling Microscope (STM) operating at very low temperatures we image the atoms and position them one-by-one into an arrangement of our choice. Local electron tunneling spectroscopy enables us to investigate the magnetic (spin) properties of the resulting structures on the atomic scale. This work provides fundamental insight into the nature of magnetic interactions inside materials and the physics of strongly correlated electrons.

profile_positions.description: As a Professor, I lead a research group working on atomic scale magnetism. In addition I teach Classical Mechanics and Quantum Physics in the BSc program Applied Physics.
profile_positions.title: Full Professor of Applied Physics

profile_positions.company: National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST)
profile_positions.description: During my Postdoc I was involved in setting up a state-of-the-art dilution refrigerator cooled STM facility. Using this system we studied the electronic properties of graphene in magnetic fields up to 14T.
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Research Associate

profile_positions.description: In Leiden I developed a 3He cooled STM system for the study of atomic scale point contacts. I also acted as a teaching assistant in Quantum Mechanics in the second year of the Physics BSc program.
profile_positions.title: PhD Candidate

profile_positions.description: At IBM I coauthored a series of seminal papers on the study of individual magnetic atoms using Inelastic Electron Tunneling Spectroscopy (IETS). These experiments form the basis for my current work on larger assemblies of magnetic atoms.
profile_positions.title: Visiting Scholar
